subject: Re: [junit] Mocking Static Classes?
msgSnippet: David, I don t have my copy of Working with Legacy Code around, but that s the best place to start.  Here s some tips from memory. Such a static method does
messageBody:
David,

I don't have my copy of "Working with Legacy Code" around, but that's
the best place to start. Here's some tips from memory.

Such a static method does work against testability, and design
flexibility. Both of the refactorings I might suggest in this situation
push you closer to a design without static methods:

1) Override the caller. You're testing some method
MyClass.doSomething() that calls DbAccess.query(query). Extract a
protected method MyClass.query(query). The base implementation uses the
static call: in your test, you can override the static method with your
own implementation. This is my usual start.

2) Extract an DbInstance object internal to the DbAccess static facade.
Then:

public class DbAccess {
DbInstance _dbInstance;
public static ResultSet query(DbQuery query) {
return _dbInstance.query(query);
}

public static setDbInstance(DbInstance instance) {
_dbInstance = instance;
}
}

Set the dbInstance to various mock objects in your tests.

David Saff

David Brady wrote:

> We use a bunch of static methods on various classes to provide
> functionality. Today I realized I have no idea how to mock these
> classes. Objects yes, classes no.
>
> Is there a good refactoring to fix this?
>
> Example:
>
> public class DbAccess {
> public static ResultSet query(DbQuery query) {
> // ...creates the necessary Db objects and returns a ResultSet
> object.
> }
> }
>
> If I want to mock the database access, I'm going to need to either swap
> DbAccess to DbAccessMock, or I'll need DbAccess.query() to redirect
> through an interceptable (mockable) interface.
>
> Is there a standard refactoring for this?
>
> Thanks,
>
> -dB
